On what’s a challenging and difficult night, I’m so inspired to see @JohnFetterman, @Booker4KY, and @JeffJacksonNC win their primaries. Each of them belongs in Congress and will fight and deliver for working people.

These results are deeply disappointing but I still believe that ultimately our movement will prove more powerful than the dark money that opposes us. More on this soon, but for now, rest up - we still have a brighter future to fight for and build.

We ran a campaign rooted in a bold vision for a politics and policies to meet this moment. Economic, climate, racial, and reproductive justice can’t wait. That’s even more true today than it was when we launched this campaign. Those fights must continue.

I’ve called @DonDavisNC & congratulated him on securing the Democratic nomination. I want to thank my family, friends, supporters, and team. There’s no group of people I’d rather be in this fight with. 

Elections are won and lost, but movements are never stopped. 💙✊🏽

This is about the fundamental right to make your own choices about your own body.
I’m someone who made the extremely difficult choice to put my life at risk by not terminating the pregnancy. I consulted with my family and my doctors. I prayed. But it was MY choice to make.

Roe is about choice as much as it’s about reproductive healthcare. No one is having the choice of an abortion forced upon them but now, people are at risk of having the choice to NOT get one, regardless of the circumstances or the risk, forced upon them.

When I was pregnant with my youngest, doctors told me that I may not survive giving birth. 

I made the deeply personal choice to risk my own life to proceed. 

No man, court, or legislature could make that choice for me.

So here's why I'm saying this: 

If Democrats want to start gaining ground in rural America, we need to get back on radio. AM/PM radio, not podcasts. 

We also need to support truly local media. When small towns' only access to news is national media, Fox wins again & again.

This is all exacerbated by the decline of small-town newspapers. Many rural Americans have had their long-term, reliable news-sources close down or syndicated. 

Often, folks deprived of their local news-source end up relying on Fox News, both radio and TV.

@Thom_Hartmann is a bright spot. With 7 million weekly listeners, he competes with the GOP hosts. 

But we need way more Thoms.

But here are some radio numbers: 

Sean Hannity - 14.5 million weekly listeners
Mark Levin - 12 million 
Glenn Beck - 10 million
Dan Bongino - 8.5 million

The Daily Podcast (NYT) - 2 million weekly listeners

It's not much of a competition.

Republicans have been persuading rural voters with conservative talk radio for decades, but most Democrats have stopped taking this issue seriously. 

In part, Democrats from more urban & wealthy demographics tend to overlook radio because they listen to podcasts.

Christian radio stations are often closely tied with the Republican party. Bible teachings or Christian rock songs often include Republican content. 

This has been a major instrument for the ever-growing alliance between Evangelical Americans & the GOP.

Radio isn't a dying media (not yet, at least). 92% of 18+ Americans listen to the radio weekly, more than TV & social media. 

And conservatism and AM/PM radio are nearly synonymous. Even stations that aren't explicitly Republican have a conservative bent.

Republicans dominate the radio. 

When I turn on the radio in rural North Carolina, I often skip through 3 conservative talk shows before I find music. 

Democrats have largely ignored the airwaves, opting instead for cable TV & social media. It's a huge mistake.
Abortion is healthcare and healthcare is a human right.

9) Right now, Congress is sitting on the Postal Service Reform Act of 2021, which would allow postal banking. 

For the sake of rural communities, low-income communities, and Black & Brown communities, I urge Congress to act quickly.

8) This idea isn’t new. From 1911 to 1967 the Post Office offered banking services. 

91% of Americans view the USPS favorably. Instead of allowing predatory lenders to feed on our communities, let's expand the role of an institution we trust. https://t.co/ZfPWHyrUcl

7) Post offices are already vital element of our rural communities. Postal banking builds on the existing postal infrastructure by having the Post Office offer financial transactions such as money orders, savings accounts, and small lending. https://t.co/Fpy4XLWqqx

6) Our economy should be centered around people, not banks. No one should be denied essential financial services because of their race, class, or zip code. 

This is where postal banking comes in:

5) Population density notwithstanding, our banking system is structurally racist. Decades of lending discrimination, redlining, and bank deserts have perpetuated racial inequality. 

Today only half of the Black population has either a savings or checking account.

https://t.co/xS4GQJATxl

Dollar stores are an invasive species of poverty. 

There are more of them in America than all McDonald's, Walmart, and Starbucks stores combined. And their proliferation isn't stopping unless we make them. 

So how do we do that?

As I've traveled across NC, nearly every rural town has a beautiful downtown with closed shops. Always, there are dollar stores on the outskirts of town, slowly putting stores & employees out of business, dragging them into poverty, making their low prices more & more essential.

They've shuttered our mom-and-pop stores, pay their employees unlivable wages, and make our community less healthy. 

But that's their business model. They prey on low-income towns in rural areas. They're the Grim Reaper of rural communities.

The closest town to my home is Gaston, NC. It's a small town with a household median income of $23,824. 

Not so long ago 2 stores opened up shop: Family Dollar & Dollar General. 

You know the story. They sold not fresh, but cheap groceries, & everyone started shopping there.

6. Equal Pay: We need to end the days where a woman is paid less than her male counterparts for the same labor. Black, Brown, and indigenous women particularly are harmed by this cruel & reckless policy. We need to end it.

5. Empowering Employees: From Senator Warren’s Accountable Capitalism Act to Senator Sanders proposals on employee ownership, to employee profit sharing, we need to ensure that workers have a seat at the table & benefit from the profits that they’re responsible for creating.

4. Paid Family Leave: We need a federal permanent paid family leave plan that ensures 12 weeks of paid leave for the birth of a child, a health condition, or to care for a spouse, friend, or family member.
3. Pass the PRO Act: NC has one of the lowest rates of union membership in the country. The PRO Act restores fairness to our economy & protect workers’ rights to join a union.
2. Establish a Living Wage: $15 is the floor & we need to pass it, and index it to inflation, immediately.
1. Abolish the Filibuster. The filibuster effectively gives a veto to Wall Street & corporations and has been used to block policies that will transform the lives of working people.

Skepticism and silence are inexcusable. We deserve better.

To support the filibuster is to not know what it means to live in a community that cannot afford inaction and that's consistently sold out in every compromise, that is abandoned and oppressed by a government we pay taxes to, in a country that we love.

I will not be silent and skeptical about a tool that is enabling attacks on my right to vote, that is condemning workers to starvation wages, that is keeping our roads unpaved, and our world on a path to climate catastrophe.

I will not be silent and skeptical about a tool that was used to protect people who were lynching Black men and Black women like my grandparents. I will not be silent and skeptical about a tool that was used to try to prevent my mom from the sacred act of casting her vote.

We can and we must create an economy that values not just the dignity of work, but also the dignity of the individuals doing that work. Workers' rights are not a matter of abstract legislation, they're an affirmation of our humanity and of our basic human rights.
We must make the PRO Act the law of the land, ensure that the minimum wage is a living wage, provide paid family leave, and pass the Domestic Workers Bill of Rights.

Union workers represent a mere 2.3% of the workforce here in North Carolina. As we seek to combat the income inequality crisis and build a 21st-century middle class, we need to maintain a steadfast commitment to strengthening unions and raising wages.
For the generations that come, we must continue to dig.

@CoryBooker has often noted that "We drink deeply from wells of freedom & liberty that we did not dig." An end to child labor, the five-day workweek, a minimum wage, these policies that we now take for granted were fought for and hard-earned by the labor movement.
I've been fortunate enough to be a member of a union in every job I've worked. I would not be where I am today had I not had that support.

"We are the change that we have been waiting for."

Where America is great, it is you who makes it so. I pray that in the coming days and months and years, our government embodies the best of who we are, not the worst. I'm grateful for every single one of you who has helped to guide our nation through these past 4 turbulent years.

The biggest failure by any administration in history left us utterly ill-equipped to take on the COVID-19 pandemic but everyday Americans rose to the occasion, sacrificing traditions, social distancing, wearing masks and taking care of their neighbors and family.
When unarmed black American's were killed by those employed to protect us, we took to the streets for the largest protests in American history.

Similarly, inexcusable inaction on gun violence has led to @AMarch4OurLives, @OurEverydayPAC, @MomsDemand, @SFGLNational and others setting out to chart a course for action and change that will ultimately lead to a safer and more moral nation.

With a POTUS who ignored science and rolled back the laws and regulations that protected our planet, groups like @sunrisemvmt sprouted up, ready to lead the fight to protect the only home God every gave us. More young people have gotten engaged then ever before.

When children were ripped from their parents arms, leaders flocked to the facilities, fighting to reunite the families and affirm the rights of every child regardless of where they were born or the color of their skin.
When the Republican congress tried to take away our healthcare, we called and marched and chanted until Obamacare was to remain the law of the land.
When muslims were banned from entering our country, we flocked to airports, lawyers volunteered, lawsuits were filed...we stood up for the diversity that makes this country great.

When a sexual predator took office, we put on our pink hats, crafted our signs, marched and got engaged like never before until it became clear that we were creating a movement for change that would outlast this moment of regression.

While 45's reign has been defined by cruelty and darkness, I've also been touched and inspired countless times over the past 4 years. While Trump has exposed the worst of who we are, so many of you have represented our very best.

As our President-elect so often says, “there’s nothing that the American people cannot do.” Together, “Yes we can!”

Happy New Year everyone!

Together, we have suffered. Together, we shall overcome. 
Together, we will have the America, that Dr. Martin Luther King, JR., dreamed, prayed and fought for - nearer now than ever before!

With Democracy itself on the ballot, more Americans voted than ever before in our nation’s history. 

Though this has been an exhausting year, in the words of Robert Frost “we have miles to go before we can sleep.” I am looking forward to taking the journey together.

More than ever, we’ve intimately felt the awful grace of God. 

In the absence of federal leadership, the American people have been up to the task, staying home, social distancing, sacrificing traditions and their freedoms for the common good.

This new year will bring us an end to the COVID pandemic and to the Trump administration. That in itself is reason for celebration and we are all indebted to folks across America who made both of those achievements possible.

We did it! 2020 is coming to an end. Just to be alive, and have survived it is a reason to give thanks and celebrate. It has been a year defined by the death of hundreds of thousands of Americans, increased racial tensions and a furthering of income inequality.

Still, like air, we will rise.

“Did you want to see me broken?
Bowed head and lowered eyes?
Shoulders falling down like teardrops,
Weakened by my soulful cries?
You may shoot me with your words,
You may cut me with your eyes,
You may kill me with your hatefulness,
But still, like air, I’ll rise.”
Instead of walking away because of the pepper spray, I’m going to stand up because of that little girl. Together, we can still get to the other side of that bridge.
Peaceful protesters, on their way to the polls, were pepper sprayed and arrested. A five year old  girl, among those pepper sprayed.
“You can redeem the soul of our nation” John Lewis told us. “Answer the highest calling of your heart and stand up for what you truly believe.”
From closed polling locations, to the rejection rate of absentee ballots, to pepper spray, they have tried to take away our vote. Our sacred right to vote.
All these years later, despite the progress that’s been made, we have not yet fully reached the other side of that bridge.
John Lewis is no longer with us, but the hatred and the institutional racism he fought against, is.

55 years ago, marching for our right  to vote, John Lewis was beaten within an inch of his life. And while his life flickered before his eyes, he was maintained by the hope of what lay on the other side of that bridge.

Follow Jenna:  @jennawadsworth, Donate to Jenna: https://t.co/3j6JLZpCd9, Volunteer for Jenna: https://t.co/sSbKAdNKDA

When we bring together urban NC and rural NC, we as a state and we as a people are unstoppable. That’s why Jenna’s platform unites NC and from the hood to the holler, propels us towards a better future.

We need an economy that works for the people. We need a government that takes climate change seriously. We need politicians who will work to eradicate racism from within our institutions. Jenna will be a leader in the fight for economic, climate and racial justice.
From wanting to invest in mental health care & solar panels to wanting to improve soil health, Jenna knows that no “detail” should be overlooked when those details determine your quality of life.

We can’t sit down while there’s a candidate on the ballot who’s offering to stand up for us. Jenna will use the powers of her office to combat climate change and protect the only home God ever gave us.

Too many lives will be touched by the results of this for us to not do what we can. The long overdue legalization of marijuana, which will improve our economy and bring us closer to racial justice, will be affected by this race.

Too much is at stake in this race for us to watch from the sidelines. For all the mothers and fathers in our cities who want to be able to feed their children food that came from our land, not a laboratory or foreign shores, their ability to do that is on the ballot.

The likelihood of our economy bouncing back, of us rebuilding in a way that creates ample opportunity for the working class and reverses the tides of income inequality will be greatly impacted by wether or not you show up for @jennawadsworth in the same way she’ll show up for you

The farm laborers who have been taken advantage of for far too long, their wages are on the ballot in this race. The incomes of farms that have been decimated by bad trade deals and even worse trade wars, their profits will be impacted by this election.

Too much is at stake in this race for us to sit it out. For all the family farms that are trying to get by in an industry increasingly dominated by corporations and monopolies, their dignity of work is at risk. Their livelihood are at risk.

If we’re serious about progress, we need to take every race on the ballot seriously. Jenna is a perfect example of why. Jenna will give a voice to the voiceless, she will see those who have been forgotten and she will lift up those who’ve been held down.

@jennawadsworth is a special candidate, one who’s running a people powered campaign that will bring big structural change to our government and tackle the pressing issues of our time. And I must note, I guarantee the legislative agenda today would’ve been totally different with a Democrat-led #NCSenate. 

This is why our vote matters, and our policies should reflect the voices of the people. They’re shouting and the #NCGA is not listening.

This means strengthening community education programs and dismantling the school-to-prison pipeline. 

The #NCSenate let us down today. 

I echo the calls from @EmancipateNC  that youth confinement is inhumane & unproductive.

So let’s vote on that, #NCGA. Money should be invested in programs that deter delinquency and violence, especially for juveniles, instead of funding prisons.

We should use money to PREVENT the need for prisons.

We must use this moment to reimagine what public safety and criminal justice look like. This means taking a holistic look at our society and saying - do we want to use police forces to brutally terrorize Black and Brown communities & then lock people behind bars forever? No & no.

It was in a bill that provided funding to implement the 2017 “Raise the Age” legislation. 

NC was the last state to ensure 16 and 17 year olds aren’t charged in the adult criminal justice system. It was necessary and important. But it is the bare minimum.

In the streets around the #NCGA, the public is demanding REFORM in policing & criminal justice. They are raising their voices and marching their feet all across the state. 

Meanwhile, at noon today, the #NCSenate convened to vote for over $10 million for youth detention.

Our state’s most vulnerable neighbors suffer the most. 
NC is a national leader in collecting racial information about COVID-19 virus patients. It must inform our policy responses.

As Melba Newsom in INDY Week notes, “the health disparities, social determinants, and structural racism are destined to collide, potentially making outcomes for African Americans worse.” The existing forces of oppression in our society are compounding.
https://t.co/PWAkrGA7rm

Black people comprise 22% of North Carolina’s population. Yet according to the most recent data released by NCDHHS today (4/8), Black people represent 38% of laboratory-confirmed cases and 35% of deaths from COVID-19. The pandemic is disproportionately impacting Black people.

https://t.co/qtu6Y3V5Tg 

Underlying racial inequities in our health system are not disappearing in North Carolina. The inequities are becoming magnified, and COVID-19 is exacerbating them to the detriment of communities of color.
